user_request: A poem about a road not taken and the difference it made.

revision_history.draft:
# What the Hands Know

The city was a place I meant to build.
I started shaping it with my left thumb—
pressing wet concrete into the second floor,
thinking *this is how it will be structured,*
when the sun came off the glass at four
and turned every window into a demand.

My hands did not pause. They thickened
where the sidewalks should have widened.
The south lane I preferred became a kind of callus—
ridge by ridge, the tarmac held its shape
the way a marriage swears it's holding together.
I drove both ways through the heat,
my palms sweating the promise off.

There was a river. I remember the salt
on my knuckles after watching it go down to gravel,
watching the silt separate like a vote
and not reaching in. The water kept leaving.
My skin cracked where the running should have been.
Every fracture mapped a region I didn't visit—
canyons of good intentions, aquifers
I pressed my thumbs into so hard
the earth absorbed them both.

Light on worn asphalt does not reflect
what wasn't there. It reflects the angle
of a man who kept making the same turn,
who wore that turn smooth as glass,
who told himself he was choosing
when he was simply the narrowst opening
in a corridor of concrete.

My hands know this: you can press
a palm flat against the longest stretch
of blacktop and feel the topography—
ridges where other people turned left
repeated so often they've become
the surface itself. My skin has learned
to crack in those same patterns.
The body organizes without being asked.
The body calluses where it was wrong.

What I didn't know until my hands told me:
you can drive the same route a thousand times
and still arrive at something
you didn't plan—the callus, say,
the blister, the particular way heat
locks in the leather seat and stays there
after you're gone. That's what happened.
That's what happens: not decision,
but accumulation. The road I took
wasn't wet because it was right.
It was wet because my hands
kept going back to it, kept pressing down,
and the earth, being patient,
never asked me once if this was what I meant.

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has genuine structural ambition — a central conceit (roads-as-hands, but *without* the speaker making choices) that could become something remarkable. The strongest passage is lines 23–28:

> Light on worn asphalt does not reflect / what wasn't there. It reflects the angle / of a man who kept making the same turn,
>
> who wore that turn smooth as glass, / who told himself he was choosing
> when he was simply the narrowest opening
> in a corridor of concrete.

This is precise, compressed, and earns its abstraction through physical detail. The shift from "told himself" to "narrowest opening" lands because it's grounded in spatial logic. That passage *is* the poem's engine.

The river section (lines 13–20) also has real texture — salt on knuckles, silt separating like a vote, cracking where running should have been. The body-against-environment imagery is doing what the brief asked for.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / self-explanation (lines 19–30).** After the strong turn at line 28 ("told himself he was choosing"), the poem becomes a thesis statement about accumulation vs. decision, and it loses its specificity. "That's what happened" (line 30) is the poem *explaining itself* to the reader rather than trusting the image to do that work. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress everything from line 29 onward. The poem should not name its own meaning. Let "you can press / a palm flat against the longest stretch" be the last word on interpretation.

**Cliché and dead language (throughout).** "Pressed wet concrete into the second floor," "the earth absorbed them both," "my skin cracked where the running should have been." These read as filler — they're decorative rather than loaded. "The south lane I preferred became a kind of callus" is close to cliché already, and "a kind of callus" inverts the conceit (hands *becoming* roads) in a way that's vague. **Direction:** Every line must contain information no other line has. The city was a place I meant to build.
I started shaping it with my left thumb—
pressing wet concrete into the second floor,
thinking *this is how it will be structured,*
when the sun came off the glass at four
and turned every window into a demand.

My wrist tightened where the south lane met tarmac.
The palm wore that turn smooth as glass,
each left repeated so often it became
the surface itself. My skin cracked
in those same patterns—canyons, say,
not of ambition but of repetition,
my thumb worn down where I pressed too long
into blacktop, into the longest stretch
of worn asphalt, feeling the topography:
ridges where others turned left so often
they became the ground.

I drove both ways through the heat.
My index finger bled on the steering wheel's rim—
that thin bright line along the leather,
the body's smallest act of civil disobedience.

There was a river. I watched it go down to gravel,
my knuckles salty, my skin cracked
where running should have been. The cracking
looked like this: the outermost layer peeling back,
revealing pink below—pink then darker pink,
the way soil darkens in a crater.

Every sidewalk I poured kept cooling into
a kind of callus, ridge by ridge, the tarmac
holding its shape the way a marriage holds
its promise even when sweated from the palms.
I didn't reach. The water left. My hands
thickened where the sidewalks should have widened.

Light on worn asphalt does not reflect
what wasn't there—only the angle
of a man whose thumb kept going back,
kept pressing down, and the earth, patient,
never asking once if this was what I meant.
My wrist a crescent. My index finger
a bright line on the wheel's dark edge.

What happened: not decision but accumulation.
The route I took wasn't wet because it was right—
it was wet because my thumb kept going back,
kept pressing, and the concrete, being patient,
absorbed both effort and intention,
never asking me once if this was what I meant.

kept pressing, and the concrete, being patient,

My wrist tightened where the south lane met tarmac.
The palm wore that turn smooth as glass. My skin cracked
where I pressed too long—canyons not of ambition
but repetition, my thumb worn down where I pressed back,
into blacktop, into the longest stretch
of worn asphalt, feeling the topography:
ridges others had sweated from, their turns so frequent
they became the ground.

My wrist a crescent. My index finger
a bright line on the wheel's dark edge.
What happened: not decision but accumulation—
the route I took wasn't wet because it was right—

my thumb kept going back,
kept pressing, and the earth, patient,
never asked once if this was what I meant.

The leather held a crease where my palm had lain so long
it wore into the grain. My knuckles cracked open
each morning like old fruit, salted.
I peeled them back to find the wheel still there,
still holding its shape against whatever hand pressed it.

My thumb left a shine through three states—
a province of the body where skin gave up
its full thickness and became surface, thin,
translucent, almost rubbery, worn down
to the white underneath, to the heat that drives
the sweating, drives the pressing, drives

the line I kept drawing on the rim.
The riverbed looked like this. The gravel look
like this. The concrete looks like this—
patient, unflinching, taken in what came,
never asking once if this was what I meant.

My wrist tightened where the south lane met tarmac.
That crease stayed. The leather learned my shape.
The callus split across its top. My thumb
went back again and left its shine through three states,

through the dark green grass, the rust-red gravel,
the grey-brown cement of the longest stretch
where turning became the ground itself.
